title: Manhattan Luxury Rents Rose 3.4% in September
text:
Luxury rents in Manhattan climbed higher in September, as strong demand continued to fuel the city’s rental market at all price points, according to a monthly report from Douglas Elliman on Thursday.



Median rent for a luxury home hit $8,473 last month, 3.4% higher than last September and nearly 6% higher than August, according to the report compiled by New York-based appraisal firm Miller Samuel. The report defines luxury as the top 10% of all new leases.

More: Manhattan Townhouse of Late Cars Frontman Ric Ocasek Relists for $13.9M

The entry-level price for luxury has climbed steadily higher in every month of 2019, wrote Jonathan Miller, chief executive of Miller Samual in the report, as “rising rents and falling concessions still define the rental market.”

At all price points, rental concessions—tools like free rent or moving costs that landlords use to attract tenants—have fallen for eight out of the last nine months. In September, landlords on average gave away 1.2 months of “free rent” with each lease, 8% less than a year ago.

Manhattan’s largest apartments have seen the greatest spike in prices over the past year. Units with three or more bedrooms leased for an average $80.53 per square foot in September, up nearly 12% from a year ago.

Studios, by comparison, have seen their rental price per square foot decline over the past year.

High-end rents have also climbed in Brooklyn, where the renters paid a median price of $6,076 for a premium home, 12.5% more than a year ago, according to the report.

A volatile sales market has fueled demand for larger and more luxurious rentals in Brooklyn and Manhattan, where new transfer taxes this summer and deflating home prices have made would-be home buyers wary.

“And as long as the sales market in the region remains soft,” said Hal Gavzie, executive manager of leasing for Douglas Elliman, “demand in the rental market should remain strong.”
